item.text: The Lord’s message against Baasha came to Jehu son of Hanani:

“I <st data-num="07311" class="">raised</st> you <st data-num="07311" class="">up</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="04480" class="">from</st> the <st data-num="06083" class="">dust</st> and <st data-num="05414" class="">made</st> you <st data-num="05057" class="">ruler</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">over</st> my <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st>. Yet you <st data-num="01980" class="">followed</st> in <st data-num="03379" class="">Jeroboam’s</st> <st data-num="01870" class="">footsteps</st><n id="2" /> and <st data-num="02398" class="">encouraged</st> my <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st> <st data-num="02398" class="">to sin</st>; their <st data-num="02403" class="">sins</st> have <st data-num="03707" class="">made</st> me <st data-num="03707" class="">angry</st>.<n id="3" />

So I am <st data-num="02005" class="">ready to</st> <st data-num="01197" class="">burn</st> <st data-num="0310" class="">up</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="01201" class="">Baasha</st> <st data-num="0310">and</st> his <st data-num="01004" class="">family</st>, and <st data-num="05414" class="">make</st> your <st data-num="01004" class="">family</st><n id="2" /> like the <st data-num="01004" class="">family</st> of <st data-num="03379" class="">Jeroboam</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="05028" class="">Nebat</st>.
Dogs will eat the members of Baasha’s family who die in the city, and the birds of the sky will eat the ones who die in the country.”
The rest of the events of Baasha’s reign, including his accomplishments and successes, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.

<st data-num="01201" class="">Baasha</st> <st data-num="07901 05973 01">passed away</st><n id="1" /> and was <st data-num="06912" class="">buried</st> in <st data-num="08656" class="">Tirzah</st>. His <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> <st data-num="0425" class="">Elah</st> <st data-num="08478" class="">replaced</st> him as <st data-num="04427" class="">king</st>.

And so it was the Lord’s message came through the prophet Jehu son of Hanani against Baasha and his family. This was because of all the evil he had done in the Lord’s view, by angering him with his deeds and becoming like Jeroboam’s dynasty, and because of how he had destroyed Jeroboam’s dynasty.
In the twenty-sixth year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Baasha’s son Elah became king over Israel; he ruled in Tirzah for two years.

His <st data-num="05650" class="">servant</st> <st data-num="02174" class="">Zimri</st>, a <st data-num="08269" class="">commander</st> of <st data-num="04276" class="">half</st> of his <st data-num="07393" class="">chariot force</st>, <st data-num="07194" class="">conspired</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">against</st> him. While <st data-num="01931" class="">Elah</st> was in <st data-num="08656" class="">Tirzah</st> <st data-num="08354" class="">drinking</st> <st data-num="07910" class="">heavily</st><n id="1" /> at the <st data-num="01004" class="">house</st> of <st data-num="0777" class="">Arza</st>, <st data-num="0834" class="">who</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">supervised</st> the <st data-num="01004" class="">palace</st> in <st data-num="08656" class="">Tirzah</st>,

<st data-num="02174" class="">Zimri</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">came in</st> and <st data-num="05221" class="">struck</st> him <st data-num="04191" class="">dead</st>. (This happened in the <st data-num="06242" class="">twenty</st>-<st data-num="07651" class="">seventh</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">year</st> of <st data-num="0609" class="">Asa’s</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">reign over</st> <st data-num="03063" class="">Judah</st>.) Zimri <st data-num="08478" class="">replaced</st> Elah as <st data-num="04427" class="">king</st>.<n id="1" />

<st data-num="01961" class="">When</st> he <st data-num="04427" class="">became king</st> and <st data-num="03427 05921">occupied</st> the <st data-num="03678" class="">throne</st>, he <st data-num="05221" class="">killed</st> <st data-num="01201" class="">Baasha’s</st> <st data-num="03605" class="">entire</st> <st data-num="01004" class="">family</st>. He did <st data-num="03808" class="">not</st> <st data-num="07604" class="">spare</st> any <st data-num="08366 07023">male</st> belonging to him; he killed his <st data-num="01350" class="">relatives</st> and his <st data-num="07453" class="">friends</st>.<n id="1" />
Zimri destroyed Baasha’s entire family, in keeping with the Lord’s message which he had spoken against Baasha through Jehu the prophet.
This happened because of all the sins which Baasha and his son Elah committed and which they made Israel commit. They angered the Lord God of Israel with their worthless idols.
The rest of the events of Elah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.

In the twenty-seventh year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Zimri became king over Israel; he ruled for seven days in Tirzah. Zimri’s revolt took place while the army was deployed in Gibbethon, which was in Philistine territory.

While <st data-num="02583" class="">deployed</st> there, the <st data-num="05971" class="">army</st> <st data-num="08085" class="">received</st> <st data-num="0559" class="">this report</st>:<n id="1" /> “<st data-num="02174" class="">Zimri</st> has <st data-num="07194" class="">conspired against</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> <st data-num="01571" class="">and</st> <st data-num="05221" class="">assassinated</st> him.”<n id="2" /> So <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st> <st data-num="04427" class="">made</st> <st data-num="06018" class="">Omri</st>, the <st data-num="08269" class="">commander</st> of the <st data-num="06635" class="">army</st>, <st data-num="04427" class="">king</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">over</st> <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st> <st data-num="01931" class="">that</st> very <st data-num="03117" class="">day</st> in the <st data-num="04264" class="">camp</st>.

<st data-num="06018" class="">Omri</st> and <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> <st data-num="03478 05973">Israel</st> <st data-num="05927" class="">went up</st> from <st data-num="01405" class="">Gibbethon</st> and <st data-num="06696 05921">besieged</st> <st data-num="08656" class="">Tirzah</st>.

<st data-num="01961" class="">When</st> <st data-num="02174" class="">Zimri</st> <st data-num="07200" class="">saw</st> <st data-num="03588" class="">that</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> was <st data-num="03920" class="">captured</st>, he <st data-num="0935" class="">went</st> <st data-num="0413" class="">into</st> the <st data-num="0759" class="">fortified area</st> of the <st data-num="04428" class="">royal</st> <st data-num="01004" class="">palace</st>. He <st data-num="08313 05921">set</st> the <st data-num="01004 04428">palace</st> <st data-num="08313 05921">on fire</st> and <st data-num="04191" class="">died</st> in the <st data-num="0784" class="">flames</st>.<n id="1" />
This happened because of the sins he committed. He did evil in the sight of the Lord and followed in Jeroboam’s footsteps and encouraged Israel to continue sinning.
The rest of the events of Zimri’s reign, including the details of his revolt, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
At that time the people of Israel were divided in their loyalties. Half the people supported Tibni son of Ginath and wanted to make him king; the other half supported Omri.
Omri’s supporters were stronger than those who supported Tibni son of Ginath. Tibni died; Omri became king.
In the thirty-first year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Omri became king over Israel. He ruled for twelve years, six of them in Tirzah.

He <st data-num="07069" class="">purchased</st> the <st data-num="02022" class="">hill</st> of <st data-num="08111" class="">Samaria</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="0854" class="">from</st> <st data-num="08106" class="">Shemer</st> for two <st data-num="03603" class="">talents</st><n id="2" /> of <st data-num="03701" class="">silver</st>. He <st data-num="01129" class="">launched a construction project</st> <st data-num="02022" class="">there</st><n id="3" /> and <st data-num="07121 08034">named</st> the <st data-num="05892 0834">city</st> he <st data-num="01129" class="">built</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">after</st> <st data-num="08034 08106">Shemer</st>, the former <st data-num="0113" class="">owner</st> of the <st data-num="02022" class="">hill</st> of <st data-num="08111" class="">Samaria</st>.
Omri did more evil in the sight of the Lord than all who were before him.
He followed in the footsteps of Jeroboam son of Nebat and encouraged Israel to sin; they angered the Lord God of Israel with their worthless idols.
The rest of the events of Omri’s reign, including his accomplishments and successes, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
Omri passed away and was buried in Samaria. His son Ahab replaced him as king.
In the thirty-eighth year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Omri’s son Ahab became king over Israel. Ahab son of Omri ruled over Israel for 22 years in Samaria.
Ahab son of Omri did more evil in the sight of the Lord than all who were before him.

<st data-num="01961" class="">As if</st> <st data-num="01980" class="">following</st> in the <st data-num="02403" class="">sinful footsteps</st> of <st data-num="03379" class="">Jeroboam</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> of <st data-num="05028" class="">Nebat</st> were <st data-num="07043" class="">not bad enough</st>, he <st data-num="03947 0802">married</st> <st data-num="0348" class="">Jezebel</st> the <st data-num="01323" class="">daughter</st> of <st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="0856" class="">Ethbaal</st> of the <st data-num="06722" class="">Sidonians</st>. Then he <st data-num="01980 05647">worshiped</st> and <st data-num="07812" class="">bowed</st> to <st data-num="01168" class="">Baal</st>.<n id="1" />

He <st data-num="06965" class="">set up</st> an <st data-num="04196" class="">altar</st> for <st data-num="01168" class="">Baal</st> in the <st data-num="01004" class="">temple</st> of <st data-num="01168" class="">Baal</st> he had <st data-num="0834 01129">built</st> in <st data-num="08111" class="">Samaria</st>.
Ahab also made an Asherah pole; he did more to anger the Lord God of Israel than all the kings of Israel who were before him.

During Ahab’s reign, Hiel the Bethelite rebuilt Jericho. Abiram, his firstborn son, died when he laid the foundation; Segub, his youngest son, died when he erected its gates, in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken through Joshua son of Nun.
